title: Why didn't we think of this sooner?
content:
Hmm... I've been thinking on it since reading this post this afternoon, and I figure if you keep the resolution at 320x200 and use mp4 or XviD compression after importing all the images into an AVI or somesuch (or even an animated GIF--I believe I stumbled across a utility that can convert those into fmv), then it might be possible to get a rather nice compression ratio.

I attempted to test the theory, but the only utility I could find for recording was FRAPS, which lagged out the framerate [on a 3200+, 1Gb RAM, Radeon 9550] and produced a 100Mb AVI from a few seconds of footage.

[hr]Alex (10 FPS + High Quality Music/Sound + 250x150 blown up to 1000 X 600 Res)
[hr]Where do you get those figures for the resolution from? The in-game resolution of the Keen games is 320x200, and 1000x600 seems a fairly arbitrary size... not to mention the fact you're duplicating pixels and making the filesize needlessly larger. Maybe it'd make things more visible for the end user without programs dodging up the full-screen image with iffy anti-aliasing, but it's not as high a priority as a compact filesize.

Also, I'd say 15fps would be better. I don't know exactly what framerate the Keen games are, but I'm sure it's at least a bit higher than 10. Anyone got some definitive info on this?

Based on a couple of screens from my mod, I figure each screenshot is an average of ~4kb. That means 40kb/sec. A decent couple of minutes then is about a meg. Fairly decent, but I'm sure we can do better with some fmv compression.

I'll look into it and see if I can find how to compress these things into something manageable for dialup users.

Just read your later post:

[hr]Alex The movie will now be a higher resolution (320x200, enlarged to 960x600), and 15 FPS.
[hr]Again, there's no need to enlarge the images, especially if you're planning on playing them back from PNGs using this utility, in which case the program can simply switch to a 320x200 full-screen, or expand the image on the fly to something larger.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

The development of the hardware, and the greater ability to express every idea that flies into a programmers head, mean that game creators have made the new games congested with every technique in their power. The basic games behind all this are so blurred that people cant catch up. We should go back to basics like Pac-Man and play in an easier, more relaxed way. -Toru Iwatani

title: Compression Session
content:
Here we go. Two mp4s, less than 1Mb each. Kinda dithery, but very decent considering their size. You'll need a media player capable of playing mp4 files, though. [url=http://www.videolan.org/vlc/]VLC[/url] is an excellent freeware one. A 6Mb download, but that's well made up for.

Edit: Fixed links...
[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/keen/video/mp4/Stones1.mp4]Alex Juggles Mimrocks[/url]
[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/keen/video/mp4/AlexK5L1.mp4]Alex - Keen5 Level1[/url]

It's a fairly long-winded process to convert them, though. Here's how I went about it:

1. Used (cracked) Advanced Batch Converter 3.9 to convert the BMPs into GIF format
2. Dragged the GIFs into UnFREEz 2.1 and saved the resulting animated GIF
3. Opened the animated GIF in Microsoft GIF Animator, Selected All and changed frame duration to .04sec (I would have used it for 2. as well, but it kept importing the files in reverse order)
4. Imported this GIF into AVIEdit with Full Frames (Uncompressed) setting, and saved an uncompressed AVI
5. Used Nero Recode 2, adjusted bitrate to around 333 (after some tweaking to work out the most ideal setting)

And voila, relatively instant low-bandwidth alternative to zipped BMPs.

Well, we've got the basics under control. Perhaps those of us with higher bandwidth (which shall include me in a short time when I finally get broadband setup) can download the full-sized versions, go through the above process (or hopefully a dramatically simplified and one, preferably using freeware tools--I'll keep working on it) and upload the corresponding mp4s.

Some extra statistics:
Stones
Raw BMP: 98.7MB
Zipped BMP: 4.61MB
PNG: 3.55MB
Animated GIF: 3.79MB
Zipped Animated GIF: 2.39MB
~333Kbps MP4: 674KB
Zipped ~333Kbps MP4: 649KB

K5L1
Raw BMP: 60.8MB
Zipped BMP: 2.53MB
PNG: N/A
Animated GIF: 2.86MB
Zipped Animated GIF: 2.48MB
~333Kbps(?) MP4: 958KB (Must've been a higher bitrate than I thought?)
Zipped ~333Kbps(?) MP4: 873KB

I'll start making some movies with this thing later.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

title: Re: YES!!!
content:
This program records whats happening on the screen at the resolution set (320x240) there are NO restrictions to what colors being displayed. I have sucessfully recorded Metal Gear Solid, Donkey Kong and Sonic with it. However, you shouldnt use this program for recording games with more than 16 colors because the size will be too large.

To set the resolution in dosbox, go to c:\program files\DosBox (or where ever you put it) and open the 'dosbox.conf' file in notepad and edit the folowing lines:

[pre] <!--EZCODE BOLD START--><strong>fullscreen=true</strong><!--EZCODE BOLD END-->fulldouble=falsefullfixed=true<!--EZCODE BOLD START--><strong>fullresolution=320x240</strong><!--EZCODE BOLD END-->output=ddrawhwscale=1.00autolock=truesensitivity=100waitonerror=truepriority=higher,normalmapperfile=mapper.txt[/pre]

[pre] [render]frameskip=0aspect=false<!--EZCODE BOLD START--><strong>scaler=none</strong><!--EZCODE BOLD END-->[/pre]

What i highlighted in bold are the most important things to be changed, however if it still dosnt record you could change the other settings. If it still dosn't work you could try using a newer version of DosBox, im using 0.63.---------
